Review: Blaster Law - Brent Knorr




All the futuristic weapons you'll ever need and more for your Spacemaster campaign

Review: Fire and Ice Addendum - Brent Knorr




It's the 32 pages which didn't make it into Fire And Ice: The Elemental Companion

The Guild Companion: Sand Law - Per-Henrik Bongo




A new elemental spell list for the children of the desert

City of Archendurn - The Preview - Guild Companion Publications and Aaron Smalley




A special preview of our first commercial module, a fantasy setting fully compatible with Rolemaster and d20 System

110128.name: The Guild Companion (Dec 2002)
110128.description:
Contents:


Words from the Wise (Guys) - Nicholas HM Caldwell


Dragonmeet 2002

The Collector - Part Three - The Guild Companion, D. Andrew Ferguson, and Jarrett Sylvestre




A d20 System-Rolemaster campaign module in four parts. This issue: PCs will meet the Collector.

Minion - Auto-attack Deck - Nigel Buckle




A competitive Minion deck with a nasty hazard strategy for MECCG

RM Professions in MERP - Rolemaster Companion VII/Alchemy Companion - Anthony Almeida




The last instalment in our comprehensive look at the suitability of later RM2 Companion professions for Middle-Earth

Review: Friends & Foes and Sauron Expansions - Nigel Buckle




Reviews of the two expansions for The Lords of the Rings Boardgame

Fighting Styles - Jamie Le Rossignol




Two Weapon Combat versus Weapon and Shield - which option do smart fighters choose?

The Psychomancer - Daniele Apa




A brand-new Mentalism spell-using profession complete with spell lists and a critical strike table

Vehicle Manual House Rules - Mark D Carlson




New variant rules and options for Spacemaster: Privateers

110129.name: The Guild Companion (Jan 2003)
110129.description:
Contents:


Words from the Wise (Guys) - Nicholas HM Caldwell


Old Books for A New Year

The Collector - Part Four - The Guild Companion, D. Andrew Ferguson, and Jarrett Sylvestre




A d20 System-Rolemaster campaign module in four parts. This issue: the final mission for the Collector and the epic climax.

Calling ALL MECCG Gamers - Wolfgang 'thorondor' Penetsdorfer




Advance warning of Lure of MECCG III

Ascowt - Nigel Buckle




A free game of racing cows

Alchemy Training Packages - Roy Altman




Alternate Treasure Companion Training Packages for the discerning Alchemist

Integrated System for Character Design - Denis Garnier




A comprehensive points-based system for character design

Additional Rules of Warfare 2 Fixed Fleets - Stephen R Wilcoxon




Fixed Fleets for later Silent Death houses.

Alternate Silent Death Events - Stephen R Wilcoxon




A medley of new house, gunboat and warhound smash events for Silent Death

Crash and Burn - Greg Schneider




A full-blown scenario for Spacemaster

110130.description:
Ha-Shin is a tabletop miniature wargame set in fantasy medieval Japan, where the forces of Light battle the forces of Darkness. It was published in issue #9 (February 2002) of Ravage, a French miniature wargaming magazine.

Each mini has several stats describing its ability to move, shoot, fight and use "Chi" powers. The most important is Action Points (AP) which represent the character's life energy.
A player's turn begins by choosing one of several tactics. Tactics influence how many figures can be activated, how many APs are recovered at the end of the turn and what figures can recover APs. The player then chooses which figures to activate, and expends the figure's APs to move, charge, use a ranged weapon or a Chi power. Each fight is duel; duel are resolved by secretly choosing a combat action for each combatant (which can give bonuses or penalties to die rolls), then rolling for initiative, then trying to beat the opponent's Armour score with 1d6 + the fighter attack score. Each damage point lowers the victim's APs, minis with no APs left must make a save roll each time they are wounded to avoid death.

The last player standing wins the game, also players are encouraged to create scenarios and alternate victory conditions.

The rules include two army lists with classic Japanese folklore figures (samurais, ninjas, shaolin monks, kappas, onis...), a set of markers and tactical advice for both featured armies (Light and Darkness).

Scale: skirmish (1 mini = 1 combatant, 1 cm = 1 m, a turn = a few seconds)
110130.name: Ha-Shin!

110131.name: The Collected Adventures of Phil and Dixie

rpgseries.10417: What's New With Phil and Dixie

110131.description:
Chaotically Neutral Humor!

from the back cover
Collected here for the first time from the pages of Dragon magazine, Phil and Dixie are your guides on a hilariously surreal look at the popular world of Role Playing Games.

Whether you're already an accomplished G.M. or a first level beginner, this early work from the demented mind of award winning cartoonist and author Phil Foglio will have you laughing out loud, no matter who's reading over your shoulder.

110132.name: Phil Foglio's What's New 2

rpgseries.10417: What's New With Phil and Dixie

110132.description:
from the back cover
Dragons and Dungeons and Weyrs, Oh My!

Phil and Dixie take us on a light-headed look at role-playing games, one of the world's most fanatically pursued pasttimes. Each month for three years, they had readers of Dragon magazine laughing at their games and themselves. Now you can enjoy the fun. Here are over a dozen of the never-before collected installments o fthe series along with the long awaited last chapter,

Sex and D&D

This edition also contains all of Phil Foglio's covers for Dragon magazine as well as the definitive lowdown on Dixie Null. What's New? 2 is the perfectaddition to any fantasy fan's or gamer's library, and certainly a good complement to the first What's New. It also serves as a fine introduction to the new series now appearing in The Duelist.

rpgseries.10417: What's New With Phil and Dixie

110133.name: The Magic Years
110133.description:
from the back cover
Join intrepid cartoon gamers Phil and Dixie as they explore the bizarre world of fantasy gaming! From computers to roleplaying to collectable cards, nothing is sacred as our heroes give an overview of their favorite hobby with all the reverance and tact it deserves.

In the early 1990s, the world of gaming was changed forever by the invention of the first Collectable Card Game: Magic the Gathering. Award-winning cartoonist Phil Foglio became involved with Magic in its early days and watched its evolution from basement industry to globe-spanning behemoth, maintaining a snide commentary every step of the way.

This collection contains all the What's New cartoon strips from The Duelist magazine, focusing on Magic the Gathering and other trading-card games.

Also included is a brand-new 8-page adventure, plus a few extra goodies for the rabid completist.

110134.name: Night of the Ninja Mastery Manual
110134.description:
subtitled Reality Role-Playing Game

from the back cover
Can you think like a Ninja?

Do you Expect the Unexpected?

Make the Impossible Possible?

Night of the Ninja Mastery Manual includes 68 pages of easy to learn player's and ninja master (NM) rules section. Inside cover contains Ninja Master data screen for easy chart and table references. Complexity level 3 needs only 2 10-sided dice to generate action, combat, suspense and hours of imaginative, intense entertainment. A brief history of the warrior ways of the ninja is included.

110135.name: Light Cut
110135.description:
User Summary

The Dark Cut series moves into lighter territory in a satiric look at the series. Rather than violent surgery on war wounds, you will be putting back together stuffed animals, unicorns and the like, than singing along after the procedure.

110136.name: Defend Atlantis
110136.description:
User Summary

Atlantis is under attack, and must be defended. Use your bubble weapon to create bubbles around enemies to float them away, or otherwise impair or destroy them. After each level you will get new bubble upgrades and be able to create larger bubbles, but be careful of your air meter!

110137.name: Founders: A More Perfect Union
110137.description:
Founders: A More Perfect Union is a trivia-plot game for 2-3 players or teams. Each turn involves roll and play, as well as the possibility of play cards.
Each player has authored a draft of the Constitution that contains the principles and protections necessary to unify the states. However, in order to present the draft at the Constitutional Convention, each author, must convince a certain number of states to join his or her delegation in support of the draft. Once the delegation is large enough, the author can travel to Philadelphia, Pennsylvania and present the draft before the convention in Independence Hall. If you are successful in persuading the convention in your favor, your draft is ratified and becomes the Constitution of the United States! Players will have to study up to prove to these learned delegates will test your knowledge and reason before choosing to give you their support.
Answer trivia questions to get your state cards necessary to go to Philadelphia, but be careful, another player might have the play cards needed to steal a member of your delegation, or just send them packing home!

110138.name: Electric Nature Quiz
110138.description:
A Wildlife trivia game.
Players are read out a question and then told to touch a box on the answer sheet with an electrode. If their answer is correct, a bulb will light up.
Player who gets the most questions right, wins.
Look at the superb artwork on the box.

115185.name: Flash Point: Fire Rescue – Fire Academy Challenge

110139.description: Urban Structures is an expansion pack for Flash Point: Fire Rescue. It is initially printed in low quantities in 2011 for supporters of the Kickstarter project for the base game. It is now available commercially. It comes with 2 additional maps as well as a "Structural Engineer" role card.
110139.name: Flash Point: Fire Rescue – Urban Structures

110140.name: Freelance Traveller (Issue 22 - Oct 2011)
110140.description:
From the Contents page:

Freelance Traveller #022: October 2011

Cover: Harry Bryan

Freelance Traveller is published monthly in PDF form by the editor. The current issue is available from the Freelance Traveller web site.

110141.name: Silverstone Circuit
110141.description:
British roll-and-move game, If you land on the red spaces, follow the instructions.
First to complete a pre-set number of laps, wins.

Silverstone, in Northamptonshire, was opened in 1948. The site was a British ex-WWII airfield.

110143.name: d20Zine (Issue 1 - Jun 2002)

rpgissuearticle.68613: "Oh, My Aching Head" - The Pros and Cons of Incorporating Psionics into Your Campaign

rpgissueversion.131768: PDF revised version - real cover art

110143.description:
The premier issue of d20Zine!

The table of contents is detailed in the Article list below.

110144.name: Iridia (Issue 1 - Apr 2006)
110144.description:
April 3, 2006

Premier issue

"Iridia will cover a variety of systems, including my out of print favorites, such as Basic D&D and Star Frontiers."

The table of contents is detailed in the Article list below.

110146.name: Reise durch die Jahreszeiten
110146.description:
This is a puzzle game using the Tiptoi (not included in the game) - an electronic pen developed by Ravensburger.

Players try to find four matching pieces (one for each season of the year) by following hints given by the Tiptoi.

The game also features a "discover mode" to provide information, music, trivia about the seasons of the year in general

110147.description:
Intoduction:

Author and game designer, Elree Ellis, is the mind behind "The World of Lucidia". Lucidia is a living, high fantasy world manifested though a series of epic works. These epic works include a series of novels, graphic novels, short stories, board games and a role-playing game. The first of his works, Islandis: A World of Lucidia Boardgame, will be released in 2012 via Time Warp Games.
Theme:

Entitled Islandis: A World of Lucidia Boardgame, this prologue will transport players to the humble beginnings of Lucidia, to a place far removed from the mainland, to a time before time, to the very birth place of life.
Islandis is the largest and most populated island in the Tokelau Sea, serving as the cornerstone for the exploration and settlement of the Asazi Isles. The island is teaming with culture, beauty, bountiful sea life, a seemingly endless supply of resources, and all of the essentials for a growing populous.
In time, through innovation and exploration, neighboring islands are discovered and populated. The new found islands introduce the Asazi people to previously undiscovered resources, thus giving life to a perpetual network of trade routes, and an incessant market place.
Island life is sublime, until...
Villages wake to the sound of chaos. The island pulses and cries with anguish. Families stumble out of their bungalows and into the night, only to find themselves dodging debris from the sky. Turning toward the summit, screams echo across the sea as bursts of lava erupt into the night sky. Dark clouds loom overhead, and no stars are watching from the night sky. Almost word for word, prophesy unfolds. This way of life is coming to an end,it is time for a new beginning.
In Islandis, each player takes on the role of a great leader of the Asazi people. It is each player’s charge to lead their tribe in this prophetic time.
Each player has a whole host of strategic colors in his pallet. Some may decide to stay on the island and continue to gather resources, make trade, and nourish culture. Others may gather resources to build vessels, explore and settle undiscovered islands. The most successful leaders will exhaust both of these options in perfect harmony. Whether choosing to make significant contributions in trade, develop high culture, or spread the seeds of their people across the vastness of the great sea, one common goal remains: To not be forgotten, to make your mark on the history of the World of Lucidia.

Game Play:

At its core, Islandis is a 1-4 player, turn based worker placement game for ages 13+; however, due to the nature of epic works, players will find that Islandis is truly a set of mini games within the whole part. In accord with the worker placement mechanic, players will enjoy fending off sea creatures, making trade, exploration, variable player powers, dice rolling, set building, and empire building (including conversion sites, villages, monoliths, colossi, and temples).
There are five primary building resources found on Islandis (Stone, Iron Ore, Gold Ore, Cotton, and Timber). These five resources, in many cases, will need to be converted into their more useful forms (Ashlar, Iron, Gold, Textiles, and Lumber). In order to upgrade resources, you will need to utilize your conversions sites, and workers. Dice serve as workers in the game and the results of a roll indicate the productivity of workers. Throughout the game players will find ways to "inspire" their workers to be more productive with the assistance of innovative tribesmen and women!
In addition to the five primary resources, and their upgraded incarnations, players will find many uses for the four major imported goods (Copal, Bamboo, Dyes, and Fruit). These imported goods are earned by lending workers to the four neighboring islands as trade.
Finally, and most important, players will need to feed their people! Players will rush for the opportunity to fish from the shore, however, due to limited space, most will be required to employ their sea vessels to earn fish. The most successful players will begin planting fruit trees early in the game to supplement the demands of fishing.
During the game, players will be able to develop culturally, allowing for a variety of new uses for the 14 resources. These cultural advancements include heirloom recipes, jewelry, musical instruments, and more, each lending their tribes the ability to earn victory points through trading cultural goods.

Goal:

The goal of each player is to earn as many victory points as possible before Islandis is destroyed by molten lava. Victory points are earned in a variety of fashions: Trading resources at the markets, developing cultural items and trading at the markets, fighting off sea creatures, surviving deadly storms, building villages, monoliths, colossi, and temples on newly discovered islands.
110147.name: Islandis: A World of Lucidia Boardgame

110149.name: Tinderbox
110149.description:
User Summary

Tinderbox is a text adventure based on the fairy tale of the same name. You are Tom, a foot-soldier, and you are destined to marry the fair princess Rowella. Her father the King, however, has taken a jaundiced view of the relationship and has imprisoned his daughter in a tower. Additionally, he has been collaborating with a malicious witch and has been ruling the land in a cruel way. It is now incumbent upon you to defeat the wicked witch and the evil King. Only thus can you gain the hand of the fair Rowella.

110150.name: Trailblazer
110150.description:
User Summary

You must guide a ball across the screen, navigating around holes and differently coloured squares. Additionally, you must reach the end of the stage without dying or time running out. Landing on different coloured squares will have various different effects on the behavior of the ball. Hence, the ball may jump, speed up, slow down, bounce back or engage in several other erratic moves. The game also supports a split-screen mode for two players.

110151.name: Wall Quoits
110151.description:
Players take turns to throw small rings made of rubber at the target board. If the ring catches on to one of the scoring hooks, that score is added to the player's total so far.

First to reach a pre-set total, wins. Or, it can be ended after a pre-set time limit and then the player with the most points, wins.

110152.name: AtomPunk
110152.description:
1-4 player co-operative card game that lets players take control of a post-apocalyptic, retro-future, caravan.

"It feels like Race for the Galaxy Vs. Magic the Gathering with a splash of euro gaming with a nuclear fallout post apocalyptic setting."

Why are you in a nuclear desert?
Players control a rag-tag caravan that contains elements of how society was before the bombs dropped. Everything from road-converted steam engines to solar harvesters staffed by inviting female engineers, and it's your job to get these guys the-hell-outta-here.
AtomPunk makes use of some inventive new puzzle-mechanics and loots the best ones from elsewhere. It steals the best bits of card interactions but dispenses with the "Spend loads of money to play with our new cards" CCG crap - it is one game. It uses resource tokens like some of our favorite euros, but keeps them in an elegant card format. Its core puzzle mechanic means that players will have to use your mind to work out the best path in this treacherous dystopian backdrop
You and your buddies are alone against the harsh wastelands. The riding is tough. Horrific mutants, shady merchants, hardened outriders, religious tech zealots and crazed robo-emus. BUT on your side you have have speed, cunning, all the guns you can handle, and transformer-like laser beam trains.

What are the mechanics?
1. You control 5 caravan elements in a horizontal line that give each card to its left and right static bonuses. These bonuses activate special abilities on the elements. You will constantly need to be thinking about getting these in the best configuration.
2. An event deck throws everything at you from crazy cleaning robots, twisted mutants, resource giving oasis, and caravan weaponry upgrades
3. Each turn pits you in a certain land. This land card tells you what resources you need to move on to the next land. After 5 of these you will come up against the 6th and final hard-as-nails boss land which will tell you the final quest you need to complete.
4. Not only do you need to conquer these 6 lands, but each player has a secret achievement goal card that they MUST complete in order to be allowed into the winning team. Will you tell your team mates yours?

How do we win?
Once you fulfill the requirements to bear the 6th and final quest land the "players" team will be successful. But only if you have succeeded your secret mission goal will you truly win, otherwise you have not won or lost, but you are cast back into the wastes, to win another day...

110153.name: Starflight 2: Trade Routes of the Cloud Nebula
110153.description:
The 1989 sequel to the successful Starflight science fiction computer game. Starflight 2 introduced many new features, including an interstellar trade-based game economy, a new combat model, and dozens of alien species, scattered across an even larger game map.

Source: Wikipedia, "Starflight 2: Trade Routes of the Cloud Nebula," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

110156.name: Amazing Island
110156.description:
From the Game Box

The only limit on Amazing Island is your imagination! Build an entire collection of monsters using a wide variety of legs, arms, wings, eyes, voices, colors and more. Once you've got your perfect monster, compete in a series of fun adn wacky Olympic-style events and party games to win even more accessories, potions and gadgets that will make your monster even cooler and more powerful.
Features:

Create your own monster and enter a series of competitions involving timing, speed and head-to-head battles.
Win monster enhancement with each victory - 20 competitions in all!
Patented "Monster Editing System" allows for nearly infinite number of monster creations, each with unique features and abilities.
Collect and trade your monsters through Game Boy Advance connectivity.

110158.name: Unepic
110158.description:
Unepic is a mixture of platform game, role game and joke that takes place in a huge castle of medieval fantasy.

It is set in the eighty's style, but completed with the most actual features that makes Unepic a very complete game.

This is Daniel, a normal guy from today: great videogame player, big lover of sci-fi movies, novice player of role games, pot-head and overall, a bit horny due to a misterious lack of success with girls.

Wait... is not Unepic a game of medieval fantasy? Why is the main character a guy from nowadays?
To find out the answer you will have to play a little bit...

The castle of Harnakon is huge, more that 200 rooms and several ambiances, all of them with their monsters and its interacted characters.

In unepic you will find more than 100 weapons to hit and slain anything that crosses your way.
A single weapon is not valid for everything. Depending on the monster you face, one class of weapon will be much better than others.

In unepic you will find tones of magic. There are 70 different spells that you can find in the following containers

Source: The Game Website.

110159.name: Deep Lift
110159.description:
User Summary

An undersea adventure. You must time your jumps precisely to make it from one platform to the next. When you jump, the game pauses for you to choose the angle of your jump. You must plan your way through levels precisely, there is no going back! Use bubbles for extra lift, grab the extra guys, and don't forget you swim move which can propel you forward.

110160.description:
In Old Men of the Forest, players collect resources that enable them to rescue orangutans – but if you waste resources while doing so, you'll be punished at the end of the game.

To set up, shuffle the fifty-card deck (cards in five suits, numbered 1-10 in each suit), then deal each player ten cards. Shuffle the 16-card orangutan deck, then lay out 4 or 5 cards face up, depending on the number of players; each orangutan shows one or more suit cards on it, and a player must possess matching cards to claim that orangutan.

Each round, the lead player lays a card on the table, then each player follows, without regard for suit. Whoever played the highest card claims one card played by another player, then either places it on the table before her or uses it (possibly with cards collected earlier) to claim an orangutan. The player discards all cards needed to claim the orangutan, and tucks any remaining cards collected under that orangutan.

Each player must claim one card, if possible, adding it to her collected cards or claiming an orangutan. Discard any unclaimed card. After all players are finished, lay out new orangutan cards (if needed), then play another round.

Once players have played all ten cards in hand, the game ends. Each player sums the points on the orangutan cards she claimed, then loses one point for each excess card tucked or collected card still on the table. The player with the highest score wins.

All profits from sales of Old Men of the Forest will be donated to the Orangutan Foundation UK.
110160.name: Old Men of the Forest

110161.name: Packy and Marlon
110161.description:
Packy and Marlon was designed to improve self-care behavior in children with juvenile diabetes. The game achieved some success with treatment groups.

A gang of rats has invaded Camp Wa-kee, and stolen the Food and Medical Supplies, hiding them in different areas of the Camp. As such, Packy and Marlon, two diabetic elephants, are tasked with retrieving the stolen goods and clearing out the malicious rodents, while also remembering to take their insulin and check their blood glucose. At the end of the game they face the evil bosses Veets and Yebur of the Lunch Room Crew.

Source: Wikipedia, "Packy and Marlon", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

110162.name: The Pagemaster
110162.description:
The Pagemaster is a video game released in conjunction with the 1994 film The Pagemaster. A character can be guided through a selection of levels based around themed books, ranging from horror to adventure and fantasy worlds. Magic can be used, and stomping enemies to death by jumping on their heads is permitted. Enemies include bats, flying books, giant hands, ghosts, pirates, and more. The PC version of the game is completely different; it is an interactive adventure game that has a plot unrelated to that of the movie.

Source: Wikipedia, "The Pagemaster (game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

110163.name: Deep Lift 2
110163.description:
User Summary

A hunt for buried deep sea treasure. Deep Lift 2 adds enemy creatures to avoid, the ability to go back, limited oxygen, the ability to use a propeller to push yourself forward, with limited energy. Far more to keep track of than the first game.

110164.name: The Peace Keepers
110164.description:
he Peace Keepers, released in Japan as Rushing Beat Shura (ラッシング・ビート 修羅). It is the third game in the Rushing Beat series, following Rival Turf! and Brawl Brothers, although the three games were localized as unrelated titles in North America. Presented in a ¾ perspective, the game is a beat 'em up which was released for the Super Nintendo. The manual of the North American release details the localized story. The game takes place in the year 2015, after the "economic wars" of 2011. The Deutchland Moldavia (DM) corporation rules most of the world and its resources, conducting mysterious genetic experiments. Four people affected by DM's research- Flynn, Echo, Al and Prokop -seek revenge on the corporation for its wrongdoings.

There are six selectable characters in the game; up to four players can play the main game mode simutaneously if the Super Multitap is connected. The game is a standard beat'em up game in which players face a slew of enemies, each with their own strengths and weaknesses. The controls are the standard punch, special attack, taunt, jump and block. There are also super moves. The Peace Keepers has multiple endings with multiple branching paths, each path with its own boss fights and cut scenes. A versus mode is also available, in which two to four players can face each other.

Source: Wikipedia, "The Peace Keepers", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

110165.name: The Guild Companion (Feb 2003)
110165.description:
Contents:


Words from the Wise (Guys) - Nicholas HM Caldwell


The Editor talks about his latest project - Construct Companion

Alternate Coinage/Commerce System - Aaron Smalley




A supplemental article for the City of Archendurn module, including an extensive price list

Playing MECCG - Hazard Play - Nigel Buckle




The first in a seven-part series on how to improve your MECCG games through better play

Rethinking Umbar - Chris Seeman




Using evidence from the History of Middle-Earth, a new picture of Umbar in the Third Age is revealed

Law and Order - Eric Brad




Our irregular series for less-experienced GMs and players looks at crime in fantasy worlds

Revised RMSR Stats and Categories - Denis Garnier




An Integrated System of Stats/Categories with new stats for Rolemaster

Rolemaster Professions in the Forgotten Realms - Chris Adams




How to use RMSS/FRP Professions in the Forgotten Realms

The Guild Companion: Crash and Burn - Two Sample Crews - Greg Schneider




Ready to Run PCs from two privateer ships for Spacemaster. A companion article to last month's "Crash and Burn" scenario.

110166.name: Vampire Rain: Altered Species
110166.description:
Vampires, known as "nightwalkers", were found to be responsible for the disappearances of civilians in the United States and in other countries. The American Information Bureau raises a black ops special forces unit which is deployed to the streets of Los Angeles.

Source: Wikipedia, "Vampire Rain," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

110167.name: The Guild Companion (Mar 2003)
110167.description:
Contents:


Words from the Wise (Guys) - Nicholas HM Caldwell


The Official Word on Essence Companion and Castles & Ruins

The Collector - The Guild Companion, D. Andrew Ferguson, and Jarrett Sylvestre




A d20 System-Rolemaster campaign module in a complete and unabridged edition

SYMKA Issue 1 - Sean McGinity




When a set of ancient Tibetan artifacts is stolen, it's time for a team of superheroes to investigate.

Fumbles in adventure design - Robert Wenner




Some thoughts on anachronisms to avoid when running traditional fantasy games

Superheroes and The World of Genetics - Sean McGinity




An introduction to the setting of our new fiction serialization

SYMKA Hero Profiles - Sean McGinity




Introducing the superheroes of the SYMKA and the World of Genetics setting

Playing MECCG - Resource Play - Nigel Buckle




The second in a seven-part series on how to improve your MECCG games through better play

Lord of the Rings Grimoire - Decipher, Inc.




A missing page from the GM Screen for Decipher's Lord of the Rings RPG

The Ruins at Deadman's Dike - Joe Mandala




A Ready-to-Run scenario for Decipher's Lord of the Rings RPG

Campaign Record Sheets for Rolemaster - Kjell Roll Elgsaas




A diverse collection of record sheets for Rolemaster campaigns

Rolemaster on the Web - Brent Knorr




Resources for RoleMaster on the Web

Covenant Generations - David Johansen




A concise introduction to a new Spacemaster universe set in the 28th century

Races of "The Covenant Generation" - David Johansen




New nonhuman races and human subspecies for Spacemaster - designed for the Covenant setting but usable in other universes to avoid

110168.name: PGA European Tour
110168.description:
PGA European Tour is a golf game for the Nintendo 64, and SNES/ Amiga CD32 consoles; it was released in 2000 and 1994 respectively. The Game Will Eventually Come Out On Wii Virtual Console In 2012.

Source: Wikipedia, "PGA European Tour (computer game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

110169.name: The Guild Companion (Apr 2003)
110169.description:
Contents:


Words from the Wise (Guys) - Nicholas HM Caldwell


The Editor talks about HARP and Construct Companion

SYMKA Issue 2 - Sean McGinity




The parahumans form an uneasy alliance as they seek information on the missing Tibetan tablets

SYMKA Weapons - Sean McGinity




A look at some of the unusual weaponry found in the SYMKA and World of Genetics setting

Playing MECCG - Combat - Nigel Buckle




The third in our seven-part series on how to improve your MECCG games through better play - Nigel crunches the numbers and lays out the odds

The MECCG Article Index - Nigel Buckle




The insider's guide on how to find all the MECCG articles published in The Guild Companion

A Shroud of Mystery in Gondor - Phillip Gladney, Joe Mandala




A Ready-to-Run adventure for Decipher's Lord of the Rings RPG

Fate, Chance, and Fudging the Dice - Eric Brad




Our continuing series of GM advice looks behind the scenes at keeping PCs alive

RoleMaster PBEM - Randy Severance




Rules for Play By E-Mail for RMSS

110170.name: Defend the North Pole
110170.description:
User Summary

You must keep bad kids from damaging the North Pole, if they get across the screen, the will reduce it's hp. You play as Santa, who cannot be damaged, but you must hit the kids with your candy cane. Power ups do not increase the lethality of Santas weapon, but make it more difficult for the kids to get past him.

110171.name: The Guild Companion (May 2003)
110171.description:
Contents:


Words from the Wise (Guys) - Nicholas HM Caldwell


The Editor talks about Leonardo da Vinci and Construct Companion

SYMKA Issue 3 - Sean McGinity




The hunt is on for the stolen Tibetan tablet and the parahumans.

Playing MECCG - Nigel Buckle




Our comprehensive look at good MECCG game-play continues with Untap, Organisation, Long Event, Site and End Phases

Gazetteer of Endor - Gabriele Quaglia, Eric Dubourg




Travel to the unknown lands of the South and East of Middle-Earth where Gandalf and the Wise dare not venture.

The Ruins at Deadman's Dike - Joe Mandala




A Ready-to-Run scenario for Decipher's Lord of the Rings RPG (A PDF Version)

Mentalism Companion - New Spells - Nicholas HM Caldwell




Sixteen new Mentalism spells for a variety of spell lists

110172.name: The Guild Companion (Jun 2003)
110172.description:
Contents:


Words from the Wise (Guys) - Nicholas HM Caldwell


The Editor

SYMKA Issue 4 - Sean McGinity




The mystery of the Tablets begins to be revealed

This Ain't Your Pa's Role-Playing Anymore - Aaron Smalley




A look into the brave new worlds of Massive Multiplayer Online Role Playing Games

Tribal - Nigel Buckle




A brand-new totally free fantasy card and dice game. All rules and card components in PDF format for ease of printing.

Playing MECCG: Part 5 The Character Draft - Nigel Buckle




Our comprehensive guide to better MECCG play looks at the Character Draft

Pretense of Presence - Dale T. A. Maxwell




An alternative look at one of Rolemaster's most innocuous seeming detection spells

110173.name: Pirates of Dark Water
110173.description:
Pirates of Dark Water video games were also released for the Super Nintendo Entertainment System and Sega Genesis systems. The Super Nintendo version was a "beat 'em up similar to Final Fight, with a slow but strong character (Ioz), a fast but weak character (Tula), and a well-balanced character (Ren). Each character has a life-draining Desperation Attack (spinning kick for Ren, ecomancer energy for Tula, and spinning punch for Ioz) and the ability to block - something not common in games of this genre. The Sega version was a side scrolling platform game with RPG elements.

Source: Wikipedia, "The Pirates of Dark Water", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

110174.name: The Guild Companion (Jul 2003)
110174.description: This page does not exist. You can edit this page to create it.

110175.name: The Guild Companion (Aug 2003)
110175.description: This page does not exist. You can edit this page to create it.

110176.name: Pop'n TwinBee: Rainbow Bell Adventures
110176.description:
Pop'n TwinBee: Rainbow Bell Adventures, released in Japan as TwinBee: Rainbow Bell Adventure, is a video game published and developed by Konami, released for the Super Famicom/Super NES. Released first in Japan, it later appeared in Europe. Rainbow Bell Adventures is a side-scrolling platform game, the first departure in a series of mostly vertically scrolling shooter games.

Rainbow Bell Adventures is a typical side-scrolling platformer, in which either Twinbee, Winbee or Gwinbee must get to the end of a stage. All characters use their punch to attack, which can be charged to unleash a punch wave. They have two sets of weapons, one of them is either a short or long-ranged weapon (a hammer for Twinbee, a lasso for Winbee, and throwing rattles for Gwinbee), and the other one is a gun, which is a reference to Detana!! Twinbee's cutscene, in which Twinbee is shown with two guns on each hand. All three can temporally fly in eight directions by propelling via a rocket pack that must be charged, as well as hover.

Aside from their weapons, the major difference between the characters is the time they require to fully charge their punch wave or their rocket propeller: Twinbee has an average charging time; Winbee charges her rocket propeller the fastest, but takes the most to charge a punch wave; Gwinbee, on the other hand, fills charges his punch quickly, but takes a while to charge his propeller.

The bell power-up from the rest of the series also appears here, and it allows any of the characters to obtain various kinds of power-ups, depending of the color of the bell, such as the sets of weapons, the gun, speed, options and invincibility. Unlike other Twinbee games, the bells are obtained by defeating enemies instead of shooting clouds.

The game also features a versus mode, in which players must defeat their opponents for three rounds.

Source: Wikipedia, "TwinBee: Rainbow Bell Adventure", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

110177.name: The Guild Companion (Sep 2003)
110177.description: This page does not exist. You can edit this page to create it.

110178.name: The Guild Companion (Oct 2003)
110178.description: This page does not exist. You can edit this page to create it.

110179.name: Power Piggs of the Dark Age
110179.description:
The video game takes place during the Dark Ages. As a group of humanoid pigs, the object is to defeat a warlord who happens to be a humanoid wolf. Each of the Power Piggs uses his own medieval weapon and uses it to defeat minor enemies that lie in his path. The first stage is a typical medieval town but it only gets more surreal from there. Doughnuts are seen as food in the game for the main characters (as it is depicted in the title screen logo).

Source: Wikipedia, "Power Piggs of the Dark Age", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

110180.name: The Guild Companion (Nov 2003)
110180.description: This page does not exist. You can edit this page to create it.

110181.name: The Guild Companion (Dec 2003)
110181.description: This page does not exist. You can edit this page to create it.

110182.name: Defend Your Nuts
110182.description:
User Summary

You are a squirrel trying to prevent wave after wave of enemies from getting your nuts. Cartoony graphics with animals, and fantasy creatures attacking you. Use a bow and arrow (unlimited ammunition), shotgun rifle and rocket, along with land mines and fences. Power up you weapon for more effect, but it will take longer.

110183.name: The Guild Companion (Jan 2004)
110183.description: This page does not exist. You can edit this page to create it.

110184.name: Putty Squad
110184.description:
Putty Squad is a 1994 video game for the SNES, and while it was also developed for the Amiga 1200, Mega Drive, and MS-DOS, these ports were ultimately unpublished. It is the sequel to Putty (1992).

Putty Squad is a platform game in which the player controls an amorphous blue blob, tasked with rescuing imprisoned putties. The player's putty can stretch in a variety of ways: sidewards to cover ground faster, squash flat to absorb pick-up items, stretch upwards to climb, morph a fist to attack, or inflate to float upwards.

Putty can collect stars that increase his attack power: at first increasing the potency of his punch, but later allowing him to blow darts, electrocute enemies or throw bombs. This star power is reduced every time Putty is hit by an enemy.

Source: Wikipedia, "Putty Squad", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

User Summary

After over 20 years, the Amiga 1200 version was released as a free download on the System 3 website on Christmas Eve 2013.

110185.name: Letter Go
110185.description:
Qubic games evidently used same 3D board for two games, Qubic and Letter Go.

Letter Go is a 3D game to form 4 letter words on a 4x4x4 grid. The contents included the 3D board and cardboard letter chits. draw chits blindly and score points for words.

110186.name: Defend Your Temple
110186.description:
User Summary

You must defend your temple against multiple waves of Assyrians. Upgrade your weapons and purchase new ones, from a pistol to a rocket launcher. Your character is invulnerable, but the temple is not. You can spend money to restore it. Money appears on the screen, and you will want to grab as much as possible to purchase new weapons. Killing Assyrians also gives money.

110188.name: Demoman
110188.description:
User Summary

You control a surprisingly mobile crane. Your mission is to clear out older buildings to make way for new. You must utilize a wrecking ball a hook, and a bulldozer shovel to destroy the buildings. Switch between the hook and the ball on the fly, upgrade your vehicle after every level. Try for a high score.

110189.description:
Expanze 2 is the first expansion pack for the Czech talisman style boardgame Duchové, Démoni a Draci.

The expansion contains 48 new cards that are added to the games basic stack, and introduces several new statistics.

The player does now have to defend himself from three new types of attack (Hypnosis, Venom, Black magic) and a new creature ability is introduced (Flying).

The goal of this expansion is to increase the difficulty of the game, playability, replayability and entertaining value.

The designer of the game said, that the expansion is best played when two sets of the new cards are used.
110189.name: Duchové, Démoni a Draci: Expanze 2

110190.name: Diamond Hollow II
110190.description:
User Summary

Very similar in gameplay and design to Diamond Hollow. But this game offers multiple gameplay modes, more upgrades, more enemies, more music, more enemies, more exploration, more achievements, bosses and multiple levels.

110191.name: Diamond Hollow
110191.description:
User Summary

Make your way out of the cave. Gather diamonds to purchase multiple upgrades to your abilities, and your weapon. Dying does not end your game, but the farther you make it, the more you can collect. Kill the slimes and other enemies to release more diamonds.

110192.name: More Brutes
110192.description: An even greater peril awaits with More Brutes! Expand the Brutes Fantasy Microgame with this add-on that includes 12 new Disposable Heroes Paper Miniatures and a total of 15 new character, weapon, and armor gimmicks/traits.

164662.name: The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game – Nightmare Deck: The Redhorn Gate

110193.description:
Game description from the publisher:
Beginning the second cycle of Adventure Packs for The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game, The Redhorn Gate allows players to experience the thrills of a mountain voyage full of surprises.

When some of Middle-earth's greatest heroes volunteer to escort Arwen to Rivendell, their pass through The Redhorn Gate begins an epic journey that will take them through bone-chilling snowstorms and hordes of enemies, into the twists and turns of the entire "Dwarrowdelf" cycle of Adventure Packs. With 60 new cards, including a new scenario and three copies of each new player card, The Redhorn Gate builds upon the encounter sets from the Khazad-dûm expansion to offer players exciting new challenges during an all-new narrative set in the Misty Mountains!
110193.name: The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game – The Redhorn Gate

110194.name: Count Down Space Game
110194.description:
1959 Toy Rocket Space Game by the Trans-o-gram Co. Yep, the same company that made cookie cutters and other baking products!

Cover states: "Force enemy rockets out of orbit.... and CONQUER OUTER SPACE!

A simple game with a spinner (1-6 values) where players move their rockets to knock others out of orbit by moving their rocket on a atomic symbol shaped track to collide with an opponents rocket to take it out of orbit.

110195.description:

regardless of domain object links or lack of database object links

110198.name: 7th Sea dice
110198.description:
user summary

The dice for the 7th sea RPG. (non d20)

a d10 in various colors, always with a bomb logo on the "10"

the old (marbled) comes in a brick of 10 dice, or sold individually. The new (translucent) comes in a blister of 10 dice.

110199.name: Bloodlines Demo Version (d20 Version)
110199.description:
From Introduction:

Welcome to Pinebox, Texas. You have 24 hours to prove you can succeed where a generation of treasure hunters has failed. Be sure to watch your step, because some secrets are better left buried and some family trees are best left unshaken.

This adventure is written for four 5th level characters. Because combat is secondary to the unfolding mystery, game masters should find it easy to scale the adventure for any party. This adventure is written for a mature audience and includes sexual situations and graphic violence.

Because this adventure relies heavily on mystery and conspiracy, characters with mind-reading abilities should be considered game-breakers! Some measures have been taken to mitigate this problem, but the GM always best knows how to balance player fun with the needs of the adventure.

User note: This is an introductory version of Bloodlines (d20 Version).

110200.name: Bloodlines (d20 Version)
110200.description:
From the publisher blurb:

The sun sinks low over the western horizon, painting the area in purple and red hues. You realize you've just searched the same area for the third time in a row. This is getting you nowhere!

You're shaken from your frustration by a feather-light touch on your shoulder and a whisper like a soft kiss in your ear. "This way," she says.

You turn around, but no one is there.

Welcome to Pinebox, Texas. There's gold buried in these hills...or at least, that's the local folklore. Join the Apollo Geocaching Challenge to race against other teams in search of a time capsule buried 100 years ago. Do you think you can succeed in 24 hours where two generations of treasure hunters failed? The race is on and the competition fierce. But be warned: there's much more to Pinebox (and the competition) than meets the eye. Some secrets are best left buried and some family trees best left unshaken.

A 3-part mini-campaign providing 20+ hours of game play.
Fully bookmarked, plus a hotlinked table of contents page.
Includes color cover, illustrations, and helpful sidebars throughout.
Includes "printer-friendly" version with all artwork and sidebars removed.
Uses the OGL Horror* magic system (included free in the appendix), and includes new spells, rituals, and artifacts.
Bloodlines is a complex horror-mystery and is more suitable for experienced GMs.




This adventure contains adult situations and graphic violence -- it's Horror after all!

110201.name: Brainwashed (d20 Version)
110201.description:
From publisher blurb:

East Texas is an unlikely spot for a commune, but Harmony Farm has a long-standing reputation in the community as a place for kooks and weirdos. Still, everyone knew the old hippies and their friends were essentially harmless. Now something is different. The residents of Harmony Farm have been recruiting on the campus of East Texas University, and everyone who visits the farm comes back different--if they come back at all.

Brainwashed takes the heroes inside a cult's rural compound to find a new recruit whom his father believes has been brainwashed. Can the heroes infiltrate the cult undetected? Will the so-called victim come quietly? Buy it today and find out!

Brainwashed is a modern horror adventure for four Novice heroes. It combines the classic style of H.P. Lovecraft with a little Hellboy thrown in for good measure. As a bonus, Brainwashed is the first adventure to integrate our Fear Effects rules right into module. Each encounter eliminates the guesswork by clearly identifying the appropriate Horror level (minor spook, medium shock, great fright). Don't worry though, while Fear Effects isn't required to run the adventure, it does add to the fun!

2 new creatures
Fear Effects-friendly
Printer-friendly version included

110202.name: Brainwashed Demo Version (d20 Version)
110202.description:
From publisher blurb:

East Texas is an unlikely spot for a commune, but Harmony Farm has a long-standing reputation in the community as a place for kooks and weirdos. Still, everyone knew the old hippies and their friends were essentially harmless. Now something is different. The residents of Harmony Farm have been recruiting on the campus of East Texas University, and everyone who visits the farm comes back different--if they come back at all.

This adventure is written for 4 fourth-level characters.

This adventure demonstrates the use of 12 to Midnight’s Fear Effects (1st Edition) rules: however, those rules are not required to play and enjoy the game. If Fear Effects is used, become familiar both with those rules and the contents of this adventure.

User note: This is an introductory version of Brainwashed (d20 Version).

110204.name: Frogger 2: Swampy's Revenge
110204.description:
Frogger 2: Swampy's Revenge is a console and computer game released in 2000. The game is part of the Frogger series, and the sequel to Frogger (1997), featuring similar 4-way movement gameplay in a 3D world with 6 different environments. Unlike its predecessor, Frogger 2 featured a choice of different characters to play with in the game, and several multiplayer modes.

Source: Wikipedia, "Frogger 2: Swampy's Revenge", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

110205.name: Five Days Until Christmas
110205.description:
From Introduction:

This adventure takes place in the final days before Christmas. If the characters are not vigilant and mindful, it could prove to be their last Noel. While Novice characters can be successful, this adventures is better suited for Seasoned characters. Combat skills will come in mighty handy at the end, but of equal importance are Investigate and Knowledge: Occult or a similar skill. If characters lack those skills, you may use Common Knowledge rolls at -2.

110206.name: Heart-Shaped Box
110206.description:
From Introduction:

Heart-Shaped Box is a short little jaunt into the world of love, romance, anger and betrayal. A witch from years past tried to use her witchcraft to make the love of her life return her affections and the resulting mistake has been taking lives and causing madness ever since. Can the heroes put an end to the pattern of love and destruction or will they fall prey to it themselves?

110207.name: Josephina's (d20 Version)
110207.description:
From Introduction:

Josephina’s is the best place in Pinebox for fresh pasta, homemade sauces, and fine wines. It's also haunted, and more than one patron has received a side of chill with their Chicken Marsala. The ghost in question is the restaurant’s founder, Eduardo Settimio. The haunting was never a problem, but now the ghost has become violent, giving the owners, Eduardo’s descendents, plenty of scares and scrapes. They’ve asked the heroes to investigate and see if they can get Grandpa Ed to settle down.

110208.name: Mistral: the Western Med 1740-48
110208.description:
Mistral is the first of a set of naval games from Red Sash Games; a series called Sea Lords.

Mistral covers the War of the Austrian Succession at sea, plus the concurrent War of Jenkin's Ear. Though relatively unknown, these conflicts, raging from 1739-1748, comprised the first "world war". The primary naval actions took place in three theatres: the English Channel and Bay of Biscay, the Caribbean, and the western Mediterranean. Forces also clashed in India, along America's eastern seaboard, and in the Pacific. Each of the other games covers one of these theatres. Mistral covers the western Mediterranean, where Spain tried to keep her lines of communication open to her army in Italy, and France's Toulon Fleet continually harassed the British.

Mistral is a two player strategy game. You command either the British or Bourbon (French and Spanish) fleets. Orders are handed down to you from your Admiralty, and you must try to fulfill them within the framework of the wider war, which is represented by a set of events. Your opponent will have orders of his own to fulfill, but with his spare forces he will be attempting to foil your plans. Success will earn you Prestige (victory points), and may even have an impact on the land campaign. You must decide when and where to commit resources, where to feint and where to strike, organising your "sail" (ships) into squadrons, and your squadrons into flotillas commanded by leaders (commodores and admirals). Maintaining sufficient forces at "battle readiness" is critical, but very difficult, since ships constantly suffer wear and tear – a battle may be won and the campaign lost. Scenarios are one year (16 turns) long, playable in 3-4 hours (the number of counters in play is quite small). The campaign game consists of a number of years pre-chosen by the players. A special campaign scenario allows the players to link Mistral with its companion Lace Wars game – Queen's Gambit.

110209.name: Josephina's (Savage Worlds Version)
110209.description:
From Introduction:

Josephina’s is the best place in Pinebox for fresh pasta, homemade sauces, and fine wines. It's also haunted, and more than one patron has received a side of chill with their Chicken Marsala. The ghost in question is the restaurant’s founder, Eduardo Settimio. The haunting was never a problem, but now the ghost has become violent, giving the owners, Eduardo’s descendents, plenty of scares and scrapes. They’ve asked the heroes to investigate and see if they can get Grandpa Ed to settle down.

110210.name: My Lucky Charms
110210.description:
From Introduction:

Everyone knows about Leprechauns. You see them in cartoons, grinning from cereal boxes and frolicking on the silver screen as fun-loving, mischievous little men in green hats. It is the legend of their gold that we all know best, though. Leprechauns were tasked with guarding the gold and treasure of the fae, hence the “pot of gold” legend. The gold could always be found at the end of a rainbow so the poor Leprechauns would forever have to move the gold to prevent its discovery by humans. Some tales say that Leprechauns sometimes reveal the location of their gold to humans when they have had too much to drink.

The truth is no where near that pretty. Leprechauns are real and human lives are their “treasure”. Pinebox is home to one and his name is Mickey. He is a serial killer that preys on young women once a year, during the days surrounding St. Patrick’s Day. No one has ever stopped him because no one even knew he existed… until now. The ghost of a previous victim now seeks to make the PCs aware of Mickey so that they might put an end to the killings. Will they succeed or simply die at the end of the rainbow?

110211.name: Vectron
110211.description:
From the manual

OBJECT OF THE GAME
On each level, construct an energy base, section by section. Add each section by moving your energy block in place and filling it with an energy blast. Work fast to complete a base before the nasties nibble it away. If a section gets nibbled, you must build it again. When you complete a base you advance to the next level. Protect your energy block against nasties who can destroy it. Shoot them down with energy blasts. Or neutralize them with special energy from an EPak. Don't run out of energy or you lose an energy block. Three energy blocks per game. When they're gone, the game is over.

110212.name: Humanspace Empires (Playtest Draft)
110212.description:
subtitle:
Science Fantasy Adventures in the Star-Faring Ancient Past
of Professor M.A.R. Barker's World of Tekumel

website blurb:
These rules include character generation, PSY and Super-Scientific powers, and sufficient combat and adventuring rules to get a party through a space dungeon. The system is essentially an iteration of my Synthetic 75 Science Fantasy Retro Roleplaying concept, a mash up of (what I consider) the best from the hottest RPGs of 1975, Dungeons & Dragons and Prof. M.A.R. Barker's Tekumel: Empire of the Petal Throne.

The draft playtest rules will be expanded with additional material and will constitute Book 1: Science Fantasy Adventures. Book 2: Space Monsters will include a selection of inimical alien fiends, bug-eyed monsters, inter-dimensional horrors, and other terrible creatures and a system for randomly generating new space monsters.

110213.name: World Championship Soccer
110213.description:
World Championship Soccer, known in Europe as World Cup Italia '90, was one of the first games released for the Sega Genesis system. It is a soccer game based on the 1990 FIFA World Cup tournament, featuring 24 different playable countries. It's the first World Cup official licensed franchise game based on FIFA World Cup featuring official logo and the mascot. The game was released in 1989.

It was ported by U.S. Gold for DOS, Amiga, Atari ST, Commodore 64 and ZX Spectrum. The game was later renamed to Sega Soccer on the Mega 6 compilation cartridge on the Mega Drive removing the Virgin Mastertronic credits.

The game presents a top-down view of a simple version of soccer (there are no fouls, substitutions, or strategies). Players must dribble and pass the ball towards one end of the field and try to score a goal by forcing the ball into the opposing team's net. When the player's team has the ball, he or she can either dribble the ball across the field, kick the ball towards the goal, pass the ball in the air to another team member, or kick the ball forward in the direction that the player is currently facing. When the opposing team has the ball, the player can switch between different team members on the field, or slide kick their opponent to dislodge the ball from their control.

When the ball goes out of bounds, the game will switch to a full-screen graphical view for a corner kick or a goal kick. If the game ends in a tie and is not an elimination round match during the championship mode, the game will switch to a graphical penalty kick view.

To start a game, the player must first select which country they would like to be. Teams are rated on a scale from 1 to 5 (5 being the best) based on four different attributes (Speed, Skill, Defense, and Keeper). The best team in the game is Brazil, while the worst two teams are the USA and Japan. Games run for 90 minutes, where each minute in the game is actually 6 seconds. There are three audio tracks during game play, chosen based on the teams in the match.

Source: Wikipedia, "World Championship Soccer", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

110214.name: Triple Score: 3 Games in 1
110214.description:
User Summary

Triple Score: 3 Games 1 is a Genesis compilation cartridge that includes the following three games:

Super Hang-On
World Championship Soccer
Columns

It was titled Mega Games I for its European release.

110215.name: Evolution Skateboarding
110215.description:
Evolution Skateboarding is a 2002 skateboarding video game released by Konami for the PlayStation 2 and GameCube. It consists of several popular skateboarders, such as Rick McCrank, Arto Saari, Kerry Getz, and Danny Way. There is also a create-a-skater feature and an unlockable character for every skater the player completes the game as. There are also sets of level specific songs such as the metal-remix of the Metal Gear Solid theme and a Castlevania theme after unlocking the Vampire Hunter. Levels are unlocked by beating a certain amount of objectives in a current level, such as collecting items like boots and other objects, performing tricks in certain areas of a level, and the occasional grinding a certain amount of meters. This game includes music by Agent Orange and H2O. The Evolution Skateboarding engine was used in the bonus skateboarding mode included in the PlayStation 2 version of Metal Gear Solid 2: Substance.

Source: Wikipedia, "Evolution Skateboarding", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

110216.name: Ruins & Riches
110216.description:
website blurb:
Ruins & Riches is a very simple fantasy role-playing game. If you are brand new to such games, Ruins & Riches will be a great stepping stone to learning the feel of how to play a fantasy role-playing game. If you find other role-playing games too difficult, then the simplicity of this game may appeal to you. This game strictly focuses on dungeon type adventures with 5 classes, 10 races, and over 140 monsters. This 36 page rule book covers everything you need from combat to magical spells.

from the introduction:
Ruins & Riches is a very simple fantasy role-playing game of
dungeon exploration. The rules are based off the board game I
created back in October of 2006, called Djarhun. Djarhun is a
board game set in a fantasy world where you choose an
adventurer and complete a grand quest. The mechanics are
simple and they work well.
...
The game focuses on areas like
dungeons, tombs, crypts, castles, and sewers. There are no rules
for wilderness, or high seas, adventurers. This is fantasy role-playing in its most raw form…even more simple than the 70’s versions of these types of games. This system is designed to get people into such games.

110217.name: NFL Blitz 20-02
110217.description:
From the Back of the GameCube Case

Real Teams. Real Players. Real Attitude!

Re-invented for the next generation consoles, the all new NFL Blitz 20-02 is over-the-top. No Refs, No Mercy, football mayhem!

-Realistic Player Models and Stadiums
-Lightening Quick 8-On-8 Blitz Format
-More Than 1500 New Animations
-Music Tracks From Method of Mayhem

110218.name: Sky Kid Deluxe
110218.description:
Sky Kid Deluxe is a horizontal scrolling shooter arcade game that was released by Namco in 1986. It runs on Namco System 86 hardware and as the name suggests, it is the sequel to Sky Kid, released in the previous year. The gameplay is more difficult than the original, and it also introduces several new enemies and missions. It has received its first ever port to a console on Namco Museum Virtual Arcade for the Xbox 360.

Source: Wikipedia, "Sky Kid Deluxe", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

110219.name: Pac & Pal
110219.description:
Pac & Pal (パック＆パル Pakku & Paru?) is an arcade game that was released only in Japan by Namco in 1983. The game ran on Namco Super Pac-Man hardware, and the object of the game was for Pac-Man to eat all the items before he was caught by the ghosts. Most of the items are fruits from the original Pac-Man game with a few new additions. Their value varies, starting with cherries at fifty points. The items had to first be unlocked by turning over cards distributed around the maze (instead of eating keys like in Super Pac-Man). Very few units still exist, as this is possibly one of the rarest Pac-Man titles to be released.

Source: Wikipedia, "Pac & Pal", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

110220.description:
1 Alternate Effect Picard (Foil Cost, Name, and Stats)

This promo was originally only available with pre-orders of the game, but can now be purchased through BoardGameGeek's Promo Store (in a 2-card set with Star Trek Deck Building Game: Human Q Promo).
110220.name: Star Trek Deck Building Game: Alternate Effect Captain Picard Promo

98242.name: Star Trek Deck Building Game: The Next Generation

110221.description:
1 Human Q (That’s right you can have Q as a crew member and his effect can be as powerful as you combo it to be) (Foil Cost, Name, and Stats)
This promo was originally only available with pre-orders of the game, but can now be purchased through BoardGameGeek's Promo Store (in a 2-card set with Star Trek Deck Building Game: Alternate Effect Captain Picard Promo).
110221.name: Star Trek Deck Building Game: Human Q Promo

98242.name: Star Trek Deck Building Game: The Next Generation

110222.name: Wordfeud
110222.description:
A free multiplayer word game for iPhone and Android devices. Challenge your friends or play against random opponents. Play at your own pace. Participate in up to 30 games simultaneously.

Wordfeud. Multiplayer word game for iPhone and Android.

A free multiplayer word game for iPhone and Android devices. Challenge your friends or play against random opponents. Play at your own pace. Participate in up to 30 games simultaneously.

Features.
Invite friends from your contact list.
Play against random opponents.
Play at your own pace.
English, French, Spanish, Dutch, Swedish, Norwegian, and Danish dictionaries.
Push notifications.

Source: The Game Website.

110223.name: Retrocalypse
110223.description:
From the text and user summary:


It's now 2282. Things are still confused, conflicted, and conflated. Humanity fights to keep tiny patches of land, and these fights further strain the possibility of survival for the species. Nobody knows what tomorrow brings. Nothing is ever certain. Strike that. Something is certain. War. War never changes.


Retrocalypse is a mashup of Fallout, using a slightly modified version of the Old School Hack rules by Kirin Robinson.

110225.name: JLA Hero Dice
110225.description:
user summary

its a dice set for the DC Universe RPG

7 special dice (d6) for the JLA Hero. Suitable for 2-4 characters.

---

This dice set was also avalabile as combo with the:

JLA Sourcebook (2000)
DC Universe Role Playing Game (Softcover)

110226.name: Adventuring Party!
110226.description:
designer's blurb:
"Adventuring Party!" is a "Party Game" style RPG. Its a good intro RPG as it handles standard fairytale and pulp adventure, its got solid mechanical choices built in (there isn't just one way to handle things) and can be learned, played (including character creation and building an adventure) in an hour. Its under 20 pages in pdf format.

from the introduction:
The game’s scope takes place in the form of an adventure scene that takes place in a dangerous location to complete a quest. The example first quest is to rescue the princess from the witches tower. The witches tower is the dangerous location, rescuing the princess is the quest, and whole ordeal is the adventure scene.

110227.name: Neoclassical Geek Revival
110227.description:
From the Foreword:
Foreword
Hello reader, and welcome to Neoclassical Geek Revival (NGR). NGR is a fantasy heartbreaker RPG; it does what you would expect out of a traditional fantasy role-playing game. While NGR will work as a complete game I have no doubt it will rarely be played as such; This game is designed expecting that you will most likely see things in this game you would like to remove and plug into your own game rather than playing it whole cloth.
This game is designed to simulate low magic fantasy, but most mechanics are equally at home in a science fiction, action or post-apocalyptic game. The rules are designed to be as setting neutral as possible while solving commonly held gripes and bad tropes. In the writing of this game I used the following as guiding principles:

1.) Funny dice are fun on their own merits
2.) Choices to make are better than problems to solve
3.) You are already familiar with role playing games
4.) You are not looking for gritty realism, but do enjoy the presence of the ‘fourth wall’
5.) Gaming is meant to be entertainment

Designer's comment:

The game features many useful rules for plugging into your own game.

- Improved stealth and social conflict resolution systems that give equal strategic depth as combat in most games. This means it is not a one roll resolution and that all classes can participate.
- An improved "build a class" section. Simple and easy to use its the "Pie" system.
- A distinct difference between priest miracles and wizard magic. Both are better mechanically than what you will find in most role-playing games.
- A simple and yet useful encumbrance system. Easy to plug into any game where you don't want players doing complicated math, but also don't want characters carrying everything.
- An improved HP system

110228.name: Dawn of the Dork Ages
110228.description:
Subtitle:
A quick start guide to Neoclassical Geek Revival

From the Introduction:
Introduction
So you or a friend of yours is looking to play a game of Neoclassical Geek Revival and don’t feel like thumbing through 110 pages to get the feel? Fret no more! This quick start guide is intended to get you playing in just a few minutes, providing you have played some sort of role-playing game before and have a printed character sheet in front of you.
...
This whole guide will be written informally as if you are sitting down at the table right now and have 10 minutes to hit the ground running. Thus you will lose much of the choice and understanding available to someone who has read the full rules.

110229.name: Into the Deep (Issue 4 - Sept 2011)
110229.description:
Table of contents:

Editor's Desk

Travellers Guide: Lanisteg

Who Are You?: Carolyne Bourne

Library Data: The Fahlnar Subsector

News Feed: An Extended History of Reavers' Deep

Back Page

110230.name: Dead Rising 2: Off the Record

videogamehonor.33114: 2012 CVA Best Game Design of the Year Nominee

110230.description:
User Summary

A what if story that tells what would have happened if Frank West (Dead Rising) had been the main character in Dead Rising 2 instead of Chuck Green. Events and character motivations are changed and new areas and weapons are available.

Frank West must survive a zombie attack in Vegas, find medication to keep his infection under control, and discover the truth of the attack.

110231.name: Weekend Warriors (Savage Worlds)
110231.description:
From publisher blurb:

One weekend a month and two weeks out of the year. That's what they say-- but with the need for troops in the middle east, you've been called up for active duty stateside. Well, it could be worse, right? After all, what could possibly go wrong while guarding a remote military research installation in the New Mexico desert?

This is the premise of Weekend Warriors, a one-shot horror adventure by Jerry Blakemore. Complete with pregenerated characters, Weekend Warriors is the perfect diversion when you need a break from your regular campaign or when your GM is MIA. This PDF is fully bookmarked, complete with color cover, illustrations, maps, player handouts, and helpful sidebars. The product zip file also contains a "printer-friendly" version.

110232.name: Weekend Warriors Demo Version (d20 Version)
110232.description:
From Introduction:

One weekend a month and two weeks a year. That is the line the recruiters use to lure young people into the Army Reserves. But in these days, when the Regular Army is stretched thin, the Reserves
are called upon with greater frequency. Six months at Camp Trepidation in New Mexico… Does anyone deserve this? That place is in the middle of nowhere. Hell would be easier to find! That is, unless Hell found Camp Trepidation first.

User note: This is an introductory version of Weekend Warriors (d20 Modern).

110233.name: Last Rites of the Black Guard Demo Edition (d20 Version)
110233.description:
From publisher blurb:

Last Rites of the Black Guard is a modern ghost story. Set in a middle-class home in an unremarkable subdivision, your characters investigate poltergeist activity that has left a family frightened and on the edge of reason. One terrifying encounter follows another, leading you to discover that even the dead can be haunted. If you and the family are able to survive, you will have to confront an ancient malevolence given new form.

110234.name: Modern Martial Arts
110234.description:
From Introduction:

Okay, first off, let’s clarify one thing. "Martial arts" tends to mean different things to different people. This isn’t wuxia or even Hong Kong action theater. These options are designed to represent the abilities of characters who are trained (or are naturally skilled) in fighting. You could just as easily add these Edges to the Combat or Professional Edge list without any mention of "martial arts."

The goal is to be able to introduce martial arts into most settings without changing the balance of the system. Generally, skill at "martial arts" is represented by a higher Fighting die type. But the Edges here can help give characters a little more flair and choice. Now, it will be a bit easier to differentiate your college wrestler (Grab and Hold) from your kickboxer (Unarmed Warrior).

110235.name: Psypher 2430: Purgatory QuickStart Guide
110235.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Psypher 2430: Purgatory QuickStart provides the basic rules needed to play in the Psypher 2430 RPG system and introduces you to Prison Planet Purgatory, the largest and most successful prison in the universe.

It includes 4 sample characters and a brief introductory mission to allow you jump right in and experience Psypher 2430 for yourself.

110236.name: Mission Pack 001: Antsern
110236.description:
From publisher blurb:

Mission Pack 001 takes you back to the prison world of Purgatory and moves the action to the mining settlement of Antsern. The miners are having trouble with raiders, saboteurs, and vicious beasts and need all the help they can get. It also contains an Antsern Wilderness encounter table and an equipment list.

110237.name: Mission Pack 002: Sustern
110237.description:
From publisher blurb:

Mission Pack 002 is a followup to the Sample Campaign from the Psypher 2430 Core Rulebook. The city of Sustern in slowly being torn apart by corrupt officials, a vicious street gang, and corporate espionage. Chief Nyl Kromberg is hiring every freelancer and mercenary he can find to fight back. The Appendix contains 3 new vehicles and 4 new equipment pieces including a SpecOps Stealth Suit!

110238.name: Psypher 2430 Core Rulebook
110238.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Psypher 2430 Core Rulebook is all you need to create a character and start playing in GameAddikts science fiction setting. This version of the rulebook is black and white and contains little artwork, making it easy for printing. Below is a little information about the different sections of the book:
Welcome to 2430 provides a brief history on mankind's journey into space, contact with alien races, and sets the stage for the game.

Life in 2430 presents you with a glimpse of daily life in 2430 and gives a little information on the organization of the Terran Alliance.

The Basic Rules and Combat Rules section provide all the necessary rules for playing the game including how the attribute and skill systems work, reputation and contacts, and the combat sequence.

Character Creation guides you step-by-step in creating your own character for playing the game.

Races introduces you the six races that make up the Khlarmond Council and provides information on several sub-species as well.

The Skills section provides 40 basic skills for characters and guidelines on making additional skills.

Equipment provides a basic list of weapons, armor, cybernetics, and electronics that your characters can start with.

Finally, the Gamemaster's Guide provides you with addition information for running your own campaigns and includes a 2 mission sample campaign.

At only 36 pages, the book may be small, but the possibilities are endless!

110239.name: The Guildsman (Issue 2 - Fall 1990)
110239.description:
Originally published in LaTeX

Cover uncredited

The table of contents is detailed in the Article list below.

110240.name: Psypher Shadows: Torchbearer QuickStart Guide
110240.description:
From publisher blurb:

Psypher Shadows is a dark fantasy RPG set on a world cursed and exiled from the rest of existence. Take up the role of an anointed warrior in the struggle to free Erslen from the shadows that are consuming it.

The Psypher Shadows: Torchbearer QuickStart Guide gives you all of the rules you'll need to play Psypher Shadows and introduces you to the cursed world of Erslen. It includes a sample campaign, three sample characters, and examples of equipment and spell lists.

110241.name: Siltstone
110241.description:
From publisher blurb:

Adventure Pack 000: Siltstone is a free sample of the Adventure Pack line that continues the campaign from the Psypher Shadows QuickStart Guide. Although the Shadow cult that was terrorizing Siltstone has been defeated, there are still tensions and problems in the small desert community that need to be dealt with.

181683.name: Sentinels of the Multiverse: Chokepoint Villain Character

boardgamecompilation.153527: Sentinels of the Multiverse: Rook City & Infernal Relics Expansion

110242.description:
Dark streets, vile sewers, and twisting alleys – all home to the terrible criminals that control this city. Welcome to Rook City, where evil never sleeps.

Sentinels of the Multiverse: Rook City, the first expansion for the cooperative comic-book themed card game Sentinels of the Multiverse, features two new, grim heroes, four terrible villains, and two challenging environments. Besides just expanding the number of characters and settings available to players, Rook City introduces new mechanisms and exciting new challenges while maintaining the rules that make Sentinels of the Multiverse work.

Heroes:
Ex-Patriette
Mr. Fixer

Villains:
Plague Rat
Spite
The Chairman/The Operative
The Matriarch

Environments:
Pike Industrial Complex
Rook City
110242.name: Sentinels of the Multiverse: Rook City

boardgameaccessory.148677: Sentinels of the Multiverse: Villain Oversized Cards

110243.name: Forgotten Foes
110243.description:
From publisher blurb:

For every light, there is a darkness...

For every hero, there is a villain...

For every adventurer, there is a monster...

Forgotten Foes is a 183-page sourcebook featuring both classic and all-new monsters for use with the Pathfinder Roleplaying Game. You'll find old favorites like the crypt thing and grick alongside newer Third Edition mainstays like the nightshades.

We've also combed through 3E-compatible monster books to bring you new versions of the nefarious inphidians and dangerous sin dragons - just to name a few!

Each monster comes fully detailed and illustrated along with its own handy lore table for those knowledgeable adventurers who think they might be able to get an advantage before battle.

Over 100 monsters are waiting to see action in your campaign. Just open the cover, add plot, and allow Forgotten Foes to take your game to the next level!

110244.name: Sword of Neurasthenia
110244.description: Sword of Neurasthenia, named from the Japanese phrase "Shinnkei-suijyaku", is a game which tests your memory. The players are studying martial arts, and they practice lessons by turning over cards and taking those actions. Players collect and use these cards to get points and compete against one another. By successfully collecting the cards, they achieve different degrees and even kill monsters with their martial arts. Fail to remember your moves, and you might suffer accidents.

110245.name: Kamisado Schnupperspiel
110245.description:
